div1.p: Carter recommends various works on yellow fever epidemiology.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Wickliffe Rose, March 1, 1919
div1.opener:
Miscellaneous
Yellow Fever
/LC
U. S. Marine Hospital,
Baltimore, Md.,
March 1, 1919.
Dr. Wickliffe Rose, General Director,
International Health Board, 61 Broadway,
New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Rose:
div1.p:
The question as to the best book onlyellow fever, with special
reference to its epidemiology, is rather a difficult one. If con-
fined to one book, I should say: Béranger Feraud's “La Fièvre
Jaune.” His “Maladie des Europeens aux Antilles” should be added
to this.

The prettiest study of an epidemic of which I know is that of
Charles Melier--the epidemic at St. Nazaire. I do not remember its
exact title. It is in French. It was a consideration of this that
gave Finlay his idea for mosquito conveyance.

A later study by Simond and Noc was made of the epidemic in Mar-
tinique and Guadeloupe--a publication of the Pasteur Institute in
1909 or /10. I disagree with not a few of their conclusions, but it
is a very good study all the same, and the only modern one that I know.

The monumental work of La Roche is standard, and if one knows
enough of yellow fever to separate the true and false, is extremely
valuable.

On the whole, the four French publications that I mentioned
would give the best epidemiology that I know--those of Beranger
Feraud should themselves suffice.
